Herein, a series of rare earth metal-modified alkaline earth metal oxide CaO Ln/CaO (Ln=La, Ce, Nd) catalysts were synthesized by sol-gel method and used for OCM reaction. Their reaction performance is not solely influenced by rare earth oxide and carrier CaO, but rather by their interaction. Specifically, the interaction between rare earth oxide and the CaO carrier can increase the surface basicity, the amount of strong basic sites and reactive oxygen species O2 -, thereby further enhancing the catalytic performance compared to rare earth oxide and the CaO carrier. In addition, the basicity of rare earth oxides affects the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the modified catalyst. The stronger the basicity of rare earth oxides, the more abundant the concentration of oxygen vacancies generated by their interaction with the carrier. The DFT calculation results indicate that the Ln/CaO (100) surface is conducive to the generation of O2 -, which easily activates methane to produce methyl radicals, and then desorb into the gas phase and couple to form C2H6. Graphical abstract Sheme 1. The OCM reaction catalyzed by Ln/CaO catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidative coupling of methane Rare earth oxide modified CaO catalysts The interaction between metal oxide and support Basic sites Reactive oxygen species Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The conversion of methane into value-added chemicals has aroused great interest and been a hot research topic in recent years [1–3]. Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM), which can directly convert cheap CH4 into precursors for chemicals such as C2H6 (C2H4), is an attractive process that is expected to replace crude oil for the production of high-value chemicals [4,5]. Compared to partial oxidation of CH4, it can reduce reaction steps and lower production costs. From an environmental perspective, OCM is also expected to produce fewer CO2 emissions than other conventional C2H4 generation processes, which is important for carbon neutrality and peak carbon goals [6]. The reaction was first proposed in 1982 [7] and used chlorine and oxygen as oxidizing agents to enable reaction at lower temperatures. Forty years have passed, thousands of catalysts have been studied for this reaction. However, the one-way C2 yield of this reaction has not yet reached the minimum industrial application requirement of 35 % [2,8,9]. On the one hand, methane is chemically inert, with bond energies of the C-H bond as high as 104 kcal•mol-1, while directed oxidative cleavage of the C-H bond is a great challenge [10]. On the other hand, the deep oxidation of methane and the generation of C2 hydrocarbons is difficult to avoid, leading to a decrease in C2 selectivity. The mechanism of OCM reaction was assumed that the C-H bond of methane breaks to generate methyl radicals on the catalyst surface, and then the methyl radicals couple in the gas phase to form ethane, which is dehydrogenated at high temperature to form C2H4, but the formation energy for the oxidation of methane to produce ethane and ethylene is higher than that deep oxidation to produce COx, making methane more susceptible to deep oxidation. Most of studies believed that the key to the OCM reaction lies in the activation of the C-H bond of methane at the reactive site [11,12]. The presence of the O- and O2 2- was first detected during the OCM reaction by Lunsford et al. and proved to be the active species in the formation of C2 products [13]. Wan et al. also identified O2 - by in situ IR and Raman techniques and proved that the O2 - species was the active oxygen species in the OCM reaction. Numerous studies have shown that the active oxygen sites of OCM in different catalyst systems are different. For irreducible catalysts such as alkali and alkaline earth metals, chemisorbed/electrophilic oxygen species such as O2 -, O2 2- and O- are the reactive oxygen species for the formation of C2 products during OCM reaction, while surface lattice oxygen is considered as an active oxygen species for deep oxidation of methane and C2 hydrocarbons [14]. For reducible metal oxide such as Na-W-Mn/SiO2, surface lattice oxygen is indeed the active oxygen species for OCM reactions, and the presence of surface electrophilic oxygen tends to lead to deep oxidation of methane to form COX [15]. It was reported that there are two pathways for the activation of gaseous oxygen on metal oxide surface: one is the activation of gas-phase oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface to generate surface active oxygen as shown in Eq. (1) [16]. The other is that the gaseous oxygen is activated at the oxygen vacancies in the bulk phase of the catalyst and then transferred to the surface. (1) O2 (gas)↔O2 (ads) +e −↔O2 −(ads) +e −↔O2 2−(ads) ↔ 2O−(ads) +2e− ↔2O2−(ads) In addition, some studies have shown that the basic sites on the surface of metal oxide catalysts are favorable for OCM reaction [17]. The generation of electron-deficient oxygen species also needs to exist stably under certain basicity. It is shown that the moderate and strong basic sites of the catalyst is vital for C2 selectivity [18]. As an alkaline earth metal oxide, CaO is widely available and inexpensive, with good thermal stability and a certain basicity, which can meet the high thermal stability and active site requirements of OCM reactions for catalysts [19,20]. To the best of our knowledge, CaO has been less studied in OCM reaction. Rare earth oxides, especially La2O3, have excellent low-temperature OCM reaction performance [21,22]. In addition, most studies have focused on alkali metal modified alkaline earth metal oxides such as Li/MgO to understand the OCM reaction mechanism [13], and alkaline earth metal modified rare earth oxides can often increase the amount of moderate and strong basic sites, further improving their low-temperature OCM reaction performance [23]. In this study, for rare earth metal modified alkaline earth metal oxides, in order to further understand the role of reactive sites in OCM reactions, we selected La, Ce and Nd to modify CaO which is because in terms of the basicity of rare earth oxides, it follows the order of La2O3 >Nd2O3 >CeO2. While for oxygen sites, both La2O3 and Nd2O3 are non-reducible, and oxygen mobility is relatively poor compared to CeO2. Herein, Ln/CaO (Ln=La, Ce, Nd) catalysts were prepared by citric acid sol-gel method for OCM reaction. The influence between the reactive sites and reaction performance of this series of catalysts has been systematically and detailly elucidated through various in situ, ex situ characterization methods and DFT calculations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation La/CaO catalyst was synthesized as follows: Ca(NO3)2•4H2O (99.99 %) and La(NO3)3•6H2O (99.99 %) were used as precursors, citric acid was used as complexant (the loading amount of rare earth oxide is 10 % wt), dissolved in 100 mL deionized water and mixed evenly. The resulting mixture solution was then stirred in a water bath at 90 °C to form a gel, which was then transferred to an oven at 160 °C overnight. Subsequently, the dried gel was transferred to a muffle furnace and heated to 900 °C at 5 °C•min-1 and roasted for 5 h to obtain La/CaO catalyst. Ce/CaO and Nd/CaO catalysts were prepared by the same method except that La(NO3)3•6H2O was replaced with Ce(NO3)3•6H2O(99.99 %) and Nd(NO3)3•6H2O(99.99 %), respectively. As a comparative study, the pure phases of CaO, La2O3, CeO2 and Nd2O3 were also synthesized by sol-gel method. 2.2 Evaluation of catalytic reaction performance and characterization of catalysts The evaluation conditions for the OCM reaction performance of the catalyst, specific catalyst characterization methods and instrument conditions, as well as the DFT calculation model are detailed in the supplementary materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Bulk and surface characterization of the catalysts To analyze the bulk phase of the fresh and spent catalysts, XRD patterns of all catalysts were analyzed. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), for pure metal oxides CaO, La2O3, CeO2 and Nd2O3, no other impurities observe and their diffraction peaks were consistent with those of the standards (jade 6.0, CaO: PDF#48–1467, La2O3: PDF#05–0602, CeO2: PDF#43–1002, Nd2O3:PDF#43–1023), testifying that pure phase metal oxides have been successfully synthesized. It is worth noting that CaO and CeO2 possess cubic crystal structure, while La2O3 and Nd2O3 exhibit hexagonal phase structure. As displayed in Fig. 1(b), the orange dashed lines represent the XRD diffraction peaks of CaO, which exhibit no 2θ angular shift. For each modified catalyst, in addition to the observable diffraction peaks of the CaO support, characteristic diffraction peaks of different rare earth oxides can also be observed, testifying that the rare earth metal cation do not replace positive ion sites of CaO to form a solid solution, but only exist on the surface of CaO in the form of oxides. Fig. S1(a) and (b) confirmed that this series of samples is stable during the OCM reaction process, as no changes in the crystal phase or the generation of other impurity peaks were observed in their XRD results. As shown in Table S1, the specific surface areas of pure metal oxides range from 5 to 10 m2/g, while that of the loaded catalyst are in the range of 7–11 m2/g. After the reaction, their specific surface areas did not undergo significant changes. XPS analysis was performed on all catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 2 (a), the binding energy located at 347.6 and 357.2 eV attributed to Ca 2p3/2 and Ca 2p1/2 confirms the existence of Ca2+ [24]. Interestingly, when it was loaded with rare earth oxides, the binding energy shifts towards lower value, according to the XRD results, no solid solution structure is formed, indicating an interaction between the rare earth oxides and the CaO. Fig. 2(b) shows the presence of La3+ is evidenced by deconvolution peaks at 851 and 834 eV and satellite peaks at 855 and 838 eV in the La 3d spectra for La2O3 and La/CaO. In addition, the binding energy difference ∆E of their La 3d5/2 spin coupling splitting is 3.4 and 3.8 eV, respectively, testifying that La3+ exists in the form of La2(CO3)3 on the surface of La2O3, while it exists in the form of La(OH)3 on the surface of La/CaO [25,26]. According to the literatures, we fitted and deconvoluted the Ce 3d spectra of the two Ce based samples into 10 peaks, the results can be found in Fig. 2(c) [27,28]. The specific binding energy values, quantified Ce3+contents are shown in Table S2. For CeO2 and Ce/CaO, the Ce3+ contents were 17.5 % and 18.4 %, respectively, indicating that the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the surface of CaO loaded with CeO2 is slightly higher than that of pure oxide. Nd 3d spectra of Nd2O3 and Nd/CaO displayed in Fig. 2(d). It proves the existence of Nd3+ due to the binding energy located at 981.9 and 1005.0 eV attributed to Nd 3d5/2 and Nd 3d3/2 [29]. It is also worth noting that the binding energy of Nd 3d spectra for the Nd/CaO catalyst is located at a lower value than that of pure Nd2O3, further demonstrating the interaction between Nd2O3 and CaO. As shown in Table S3, the ICP results indicate that their rare earth oxide loading amount are all close to10 %wt. Similarly, XPS calculations reveal that the surface content of rare earth oxide is close to their bulk content. 3.2 Reaction performance The catalytic performance of pure metal oxide and modified Ln/CaO (Ln=La, Ce, Nd) catalysts on OCM reaction was evaluated. To further accurately obtain their reaction performance, we also conducted OCM reaction performance tests on empty quartz tubes and found that their reaction performance was almost negligible. We took the average of their three reaction performance test results and deducted the influence of the empty quartz tube. The results are shown in Fig. 3 (a–c). It can be clearly seen that for the CaO support, the OCM reaction performance is very poor below 600 °C. Even at 650 °C, the CH4 conversion is still lower than pure metal oxides and modified catalysts. As the reaction temperature increases, its reaction performance further improves, and 31.4 % of CH4 conversion, 41.0 % of C2 selectivity and 12.9 % of C2 yield can be obtained at 750 °C. Rare earth oxides have better low-temperature OCM reaction performance than CaO. At 550 °C, their CH4 conversion follows the order of La2O3 >Nd2O3 >CeO2. It is worth noting that the C2 selectivity of CeO2 in the reaction temperature range is very poor. La2O3 and Nd2O3 can obtain 27.3 % and 27.5 % of CH4 conversion, and 35.7 % and 29.7 % of C2 selectivity at 550 °C, respectively. At this temperature, the C2 yields of La2O3 and Nd2O3 were 9.9 % and 8.2 %, respectively. With the further increase of reaction temperature, the reaction performance of La2O3 increased, and the maximum reaction performance was obtained at 750 °C, with the CH4 conversion, C2 selectivity and C2 yield of 31.3 %, 44.4 % and 13.8 %, respectively. For Nd2O3, with the increase of reaction temperature, the reaction performance first increased and then decreased, and the best reaction performance was obtained at 600 °C. The CH4 conversion, C2 selectivity and C2 yield were 28.2 %, 32.0 % and 9.0 %, respectively. Interestingly, at 550 °C, when rare earth oxides are loaded onto a CaO support, their reaction performance significantly decreases compared to the corresponding rare earth oxides. However, when the reaction temperature reaches 600 °C or above, the OCM reaction performance of all modified catalysts is generally higher than the corresponding rare earth oxides and CaO, testifying that the reaction performance of the modified catalyst does not solely depend on the support or rare earth oxide, but rather on the interaction between them. The reaction performance almost obeys the sequence of La/CaO >Nd/CaO >Ce/CaO. The most notable is Ce/CaO. At 600 °C, both CeO2 and CaO exhibit poor reaction performance, whereas Ce/CaO achieves a CH4 conversion of 25.6 %, a C2 selectivity of 42.6 %, and a C2 yield of 10.9 % at the same temperature. Compared to CaO and CeO2, the interaction between them significantly enhances their low-temperature OCM reaction performance. In addition, for these modified catalysts, their OCM reaction performance initially increases and then decreases with increasing reaction temperature. Specifically, La/CaO can achieve a C2 yield of 16.9 % at 700 °C, while Ce/CaO and Nd/CaO achieve their maximum C2 yields at the same temperature, which are 13.4 % and 13.6 %, respectively. We selected two catalysts, La/CaO with the best reaction performance and Ce/LaO with the worst reaction performance, and tested their reaction stability for 100 h at 750 °C. As displayed in Fig. 3(c) and (d), the reaction performance of these two catalysts has not significantly decreased. The OCM reaction performance test results indicate that the interaction between rare earth oxides and CaO is conducive to enhancing the OCM reaction performance compared to the corresponding rare earth oxides and CaO. 3.3 Basicity and basic sites Numerous studies have shown that the surface basicity and the amount of basic sites of Li/MgO and rare earth oxides are beneficial to the OCM reaction performance [13,20]. Early research also found that these metal oxides possess strong surface basicity and abundant basic sites, which are conducive to C2 selectivity [9,30]. Based on this, we utilized CO2-TPD, FTIR, and XPS O1 s to investigate the basicity and basic sites of these catalysts. CO2-TPD profiles and the quantified results of these catalysts can be found in Fig. 4 (a) and Table 1 . According to their desorption temperatures, weak basic sites are those with desorption temperatures below 300 °C, moderate basic sites are those with desorption temperatures between 300 and 600 °C, and strong basic sites are those with desorption temperatures above 600 °C [31]. For La2O3 and Nd2O3, the CO2 desorption peaks of moderate basic sites can be observed at 398 and 367 °C, while CeO2 shows almost no CO2 desorption peaks of basic sites. Compared with the rare earth oxides and CaO support, the moderate basic of the modified catalysts disappeared, while the CO2 desorption temperature of the strong basic sites increased, confirming that the interaction between rare earth oxides and the CaO support increased the basicity of the pure metal oxides. In addition, two types of strong basic sites can be observed in La/CaO. According to their reaction performance, La2O3 and Nd2O3 have good low-temperature OCM reaction performance at 550 °C, which may be related to their moderate basic sites. When they were loaded on of CaO, the moderate basic sites disappeared and the amount of strong basic sites increased. La/CaO exhibits good high-temperature OCM reaction performance, which can be attributed to the increase in the number and amount of strong basic sites due to the interaction between La2O3 and CaO support. Furthermore, compared with the CaO support and pure rare earth oxides, the amount of basic sites of modified catalysts is increased, as a result, their reaction performance is also better than that of pure metal oxides. Research has shown that the wavenumber difference between the symmetric and antisymmetric stretching vibrations of surface monodentate carbonates of metal oxides in FTIR spectra can be used to measure the basicity [32]. The smaller the wavenumber difference, the stronger the basicity [32]. The FTIR spectra of pure metal oxides and modified catalysts can be found in Fig. 4(b) and (c). The IR bands at ∼3600, ∼1500 and ∼500 cm-1 could be attributed to stretching vibrations of O-H bonds of hydroxyl group, monodentate carbonates, and metal-oxygen bonds, respectively [33,34]. For pure metal oxides, the wavenumber difference between symmetrical and antisymmetric stretching vibrations of their monodentate carbonates (∼1460, ∼1390 cm-1) conforms to CaO< La2O3 <Nd2O3, indicating that their basicity follows the sequence of CaO >La2O3 >Nd2O3. This is consistent with the basicity of alkaline earth metal oxides is stronger than that of rare earth oxides. The monodentate carbonate peak intensity of CeO2 is low and wide, testifying that its basicity is the weakest. Interestingly, when the rare earth oxide is loaded on CaO, their wavenumber difference is smaller than that of CaO and rare earth oxides, indicating that the basicity of the modified catalyst is stronger than that of pure metal oxides, which is consistent with the results of CO2-TPD. Their basicity order is La/CaO >Nd/CaO >Ce/CaO. Due to the adsorption of water and CO2 from the air to form hydroxyl groups and surface carbonates on the metal oxide surface, the XPS O 1 s spectra tested at ambient condition cannot directly reflect oxygen vacancies and various active oxygen species of metal oxides [35]. It still does not affect the characterization of basic sites. This is because weak basic sites are mostly surface hydroxyl groups of metal oxides, and the amount of carbonates can indirectly reflect the amount of basic sites [36]. XPS O1 s spectra and quantified results of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 5 and Table S4, sub-peak fitting based on the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of each oxygen species in the range of 1.8–2.0 eV. As displayed in Fig. 5(a), for pure metal oxides, the binding energy located at 531.5 eV attributes to surface OH/CO3 2-, and the binding energy at 529.5 eV can be assigned to surface lattice oxygen O2- [37]. The ratio of A − OH / CO 3 2 − / A O 2 − of the pure metal oxides obeys the order of CaO (23.8) >La2O3 (9.0) >Nd2O3 (1.7) >CeO2 (0.5), which is highly consistent with their basicity and the abundance of their basic sites. As displayed in Fig. 5(b), the ratio of the modified catalyst further increases, which follows the order of La/CaO (96.1) >Nd/CaO (57.8) >Ce/CaO (17.4). Their XPS O1 s results are also consistent with the amount of basic sites determined by CO2-TPD and the strength of basicity determined by FTIR. The above results indicate that the basicity and the amount of basic sites of the catalysts are important factors affecting their reaction performance. The moderate basic sites are beneficial to the low-temperature OCM reaction performance. The basicity and the amount of basic sites for the modified catalyst are further improved, not solely from rare earth oxides and CaO, but from their interaction. This is the fundamental reason for the improvement of their reaction performance. 3.4 Characterization of reactive oxygen sites Numerous studies have reported that for alkaline earth metal oxides, rare earth oxides, or alkali metal-modified alkaline earth metal oxides such as Li/MgO catalysts, their OCM active oxygen species are electron-deficient oxygen species such as O2 -, O2 2-, or O-, which play a role in activating the C-H bond of methane molecules and facilitating the formation of C2 products [31,38]. To investigate the reactive oxygen species of this series of catalysts, we conducted O2-TPD experiments. The O2-TPD profiles and quantitative results of pure oxide and modified catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 (a) and Table 2 , respectively. The sample was first treated in a 10 % O2-Ar atmosphere for 30 min at 800 °C to eliminate interference from surface carbonates and other impurities. Then, it was cooled down to 50 °C. After adsorbing O2 at the same temperature for 30 min, high-purity Ar was used to purge for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed oxygen. The temperature was then raised at a rate of 10 °C/min to 800 °C, and the signal of the oxygen desorption peak was recorded. This operation ensures that the observed desorption peak is due to the desorption of oxygen species, without being interfered by peaks generated by the decomposition of surface carbonates. For pure metal oxides and modified catalysts, the desorption peak below 300 °C represents the desorption of loosely bound oxygen species, while the desorption peak between 300 and 600 °C attributes the desorption of chemisorbed oxygen species. The desorption peak exceeding 600 °C indicates the desorption of surface lattice oxygen species [12,39]. It can be observed that for the CaO support and pure rare earth oxides, the desorption temperature of chemisorbed oxygen on CaO is higher than that on La2O3 and Nd2O3. However, for CeO2, almost no desorption of chemisorbed oxygen is observed, similar to the CO2-TPD results. Due to the lower desorption temperature of chemisorbed oxygen on La2O3 and Nd2O3, their low-temperature OCM reaction performance is relative good. When rare earth oxides are loaded on CaO, the chemisorbed oxygen desorption amount increases, which follows the order of La/CaO >Nd/CaO >Ce/CaO. Additionally, the desorption temperature further increases, which can also well correlate with their reaction performance. Furthermore, their O2-TPD profiles are very similar to CO2-TPD profiles, indicating that active oxygen species are closely related to basic sites. The results of reaction performance testing, characterization of basic sites, and O2-TPD demonstrate that the interaction between rare earth oxides and CaO is the essential factor affecting the reaction performance of the modified catalysts Ln/Ca (Ln=La, Ce, Nd). This interaction raises the desorption temperature of strong basic sites and chemisorbed oxygen, and increases the amount of these two types of reactive sites, thereby enhancing the OCM reaction performance. To further study the OCM reactive oxygen species of the modified catalysts, EPR characterization was performed. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the oxygen vacancy characteristic signal of g = 2.003 can be observed for all the catalysts [40]. The order of signal intensity was La/CaO >Nd/CaO >Ce/CaO, which was consistent with the amount of chemisorbed oxygen and their reaction performance. In addition, it is closely related to the basicity of rare earth oxides. The stronger the basicity of rare earth oxides, the richer the oxygen vacancies generated by their interaction with the carrier CaO. To further clarify the reactive oxygen species in the OCM reaction of the modified catalysts, we selected La/CaO, which exhibits the best reaction performance, and Ce/LaO, which possesses the worst reaction performance for CH4-TPSR-MS, as well as CH4 pulse after oxygen adsorption experiments. The sample was first pretreated at 800 °C in a high-purity Ar atmosphere for 30 min to remove surface carbonate species and chemisorbed oxygen species, then cooled down to 100 °C. A mixed gas of CH4:Ar=3:5 was introduced, and the temperature was raised at a rate of 10 °C/min to 800 °C. Since both C2H4 and C2H6 exhibit the same MS signal at m/z=27, and the molecular ion peak of CO at m/z=28 interferes with C2H4, C2H6, and CO2, therefore, the MS signals of m/z=27 (C2 products) and m/z=44 (CO2) were recorded. As shown in Fig. 7 (a) and (b), no C2 products were generated by either catalyst within the reaction temperature range, but a significant CO2 peak was present. Additionally, the CO2 peak area of Ce/CaO was significantly larger than that of La/CaO, indicating that after the removal of chemisorbed oxygen for both catalysts, surface lattice oxygen reacted with methane to generate the deep oxidation product CO2. Furthermore, it can be concluded that the surface lattice oxygen of Ce/CaO is more abundant than that of La/CaO. After the sample was pretreated at 750 °C in 10 % O2-Ar for 30 min, high-purity Ar was used to purge the surface for 5 min to remove physically adsorbed oxygen. Subsequently, 1 mL of CH4 was introduced in pulse. The results are shown in Fig. 7(c) and (d). Both catalysts produced C2 products, which clearly demonstrates that chemisorbed oxygen species are the reactive oxygen species for OCM reaction. Furthermore, the amount of CO2 produced by Ce/CaO is still higher than that of La/CaO, further indicating that the lattice oxygen of Ce/CaO is more abundant than that of La/CaO. 3.5 Identification the types of reactive oxygen species To identify the types of reactive oxygen species for OCM reaction in this series of catalysts, we conducted in situ Raman and DRIFTS experiments on La/CaO and Ce/CaO catalysts. The samples were treated with a 10 % O2-Ar atmosphere at 700 °C for 1 h to remove any impurities from the catalyst surface, which was then adsorbed and saturated to O2. The Raman spectra were measured in the same atmosphere and temperature. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), two Raman bands at 685 and 1085 cm-1 can be observed. These bands attribute to O2 2- and O2 - species [41]. However, the Raman bands of carbonate are also at 1085 cm-1, so it is difficult to determine the presence of O2 - through Raman spectra. Therefore, we further conducted in situ DRFTS experiments on these two catalysts. The samples were first pretreated at 700 °C in a high-purity Ar atmosphere for remove surface impurities, resulting in the IR spectra of a. Subsequently, it was exposed to a 10 % O2-Ar mixture and IR spectra b, c, and d were collected at 5 min, 15 mins, and 30 min, respectively. With the increase in exposure time, the IR bands at 1150 and 1070 cm-1 gradually intensify. These two peaks can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of O2 - species [42]. The intensities of other IR peaks do not vary significantly can be attributed to the carbonates. No IR bands at 850–870 cm-1 attributed to O2 2- can be observed for these two catalysts, However, Raman spectra indeed detect the presence of O2 2-. This is because that gaseous oxygen reacts with surface lattice oxygen of rare earth oxides such as La2O3 under laser promotion to generate O2 2- [43]. Combining these two spectra, it can be determined that O2 - is the reactive oxygen species for OCM reaction. 3.6 DFT calculation results We select the CaO (100) surface for DFT calculation is considered to be a low refractive index plane of face-centered cubic structure with low surface energy [44]. O2 was adsorbed on La/CaO (100) and Ce/CaO (100) surfaces, respectively (Fig. 9 (a)). The E abs of O2 on the surface of La/CaO (100) was −3.30 eV, and the length of O-O bond was extended from 1.234 Å to 1.303 Å, which was activated to O2 - on the surface. The distance between O-O in the process of surface dissociated O2 activation was changed from 2.01 Å in the transition state to 3.41 Å in the final state, forming two free oxygen atoms with an energy barrier of 1.90 eV. The Eabs of O2 on the surface of Ce/CaO (100) was −3.08 eV, which was relatively weak compared with that on the surface of La/CaO (100), and it was easier to dissociate O2 into free O atoms. From the above analysis, it can be seen that La/CaO (100) surface adsorbs O2 and activates O2 into O2 - more easily, which is consistent with the results of EPR and O2-TPD results. The E a of O2 - to CH4 on La-CaO (100) and Ce-CaO (100) surfaces were 1.60 eV and 1.43 eV, respectively, and then O2 - were converted to O2 2-, and the generated CH3 were released into the gas phase as shown in Fig. 9(b). Therefore, O2 - on Ce-CaO (100) surface has relatively poor activation energy for CH4, while O2 - on La/CaO (100) surface is more likely to activate CH4, and the released CH3• are coupled in the gas phase to generate C2H6.The adsorption capacities of the two catalysts for CO2 were calculated (Fig. 9(c) and (d)).The adsorption capacity of La/CaO (100) surface for CO2 was −1.63 eV, whereas that of Ce/CaO (100) surface for CO2 was −1 .49eV. CO2 as an acidic gas is more easily adsorbed on the basic sites. From the above calculations, it can be seen that the easier adsorption of CO2 on the surface of La/CaO (100) proved that it was more basic, which was consistent with the CO2-TPD results. 4 Conclusion In this study, we synthesized a series of rare earth metal modified alkaline earth metal oxide CaO, denoted as Ln/CaO (Ln=La, Ce, Nd), using the sol-gel method for the oxidative coupling of methane. The reaction performance test results indicate that the catalytic performance of this series of catalysts does not solely originate from the rare earth oxide or the support CaO, but rather from their interaction. The interaction between rare earth oxide and the support CaO enhances the basicity of the catalyst, the amount of strong basic sites and chemisorbed oxygen species, thereby improving the reaction performance. O2 - species are the reactive oxygen species of this series of catalysts. The amount of reactive oxygen species is closely related to the concentration of oxygen vacancies, and the basicity of rare earth oxide affects the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the modified catalyst. The stronger the basicity of rare earth oxide, the more abundant the oxygen vacancies generated by its interaction with CaO. Meanwhile, DFT calculations confirmed that Ln/CaO (100) surface was more likely to activate O2 to form O2 - species. In the presence of O2 - species, methane was more likely to be activated to methyl radicals and released into the gas phase. coredata.dc:description: Herein, a series of rare earth metal-modified alkaline earth metal oxide CaO Ln/CaO (Ln=La, Ce, Nd) catalysts were synthesized by sol-gel method and used for OCM reaction. Their reaction performance is not solely influenced by rare earth oxide and carrier CaO, but rather by their interaction. Specifically, the interaction between rare earth oxide and the CaO carrier can increase the surface basicity, the amount of strong basic sites and reactive oxygen species O2 -, thereby further enhancing the catalytic performance compared to rare earth oxide and the CaO carrier. In addition, the basicity of rare earth oxides affects the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the modified catalyst. The stronger the basicity of rare earth oxides, the more abundant the concentration of oxygen vacancies generated by their interaction with the carrier. The DFT calculation results indicate that the Ln/CaO (100) surface is conducive to the generation of O2 -, which easily activates methane to produce methyl radicals, and then desorb into the gas phase and couple to form C2H6.
